thread.title: The Bears lost to that bunch of stiffs?
thread.title_full: The Bears lost to that bunch of stiffs? - Chicago Tribune

author: Steve Rosenbloom
title: The Bears lost to that bunch of stiffs?
text:
The Lions came into Sunday’s game 0-5 and had to play without their top two tight ends, their top safety, their best defensive tackle and No. 2 running back.
And the Bears lost to that raggedy bunch, giving up 155 yards on the ground to a team that can’t run the ball.
The Lions were coming off a game in which quarterback Matthew Stafford was benched while some of his teammates quit.
And the Bears lost to that team of stiffs, letting Stafford throw for more than 400 yards and four TDs.
The Bears came to Detroit amid talk of a possible Lions coaching search because they were the 2015 version of the 2014 Bears.
And the Bears lost to that gang of goofs because, in part, new Bears coach John Fox again displayed an inability to manage the clock, arguably costing his team a chance to win in regulation.
The Bears welcomed back their top two receivers and had use of their top tight end, who was questionable coming in.
And the Bears still lost to a group of oafs as their No. 1 tight end dropped passes all over the place.
The Lions came in ranked in the bottom third of the league in points allowed, a team trying to give away games and pretty successful at it, frankly.
And the Bears couldn’t beat that raggedy bunch, going just 3-for-8 in the red zone.
The Bears’ best unit was the Lions punt return team. That’s how raggedy a bunch the Bears were.
Twice the Lions touched punts that the Bears recovered. On a punt in overtime, Golden Tate returned it to midfield, but the Lions were flagged for a block in the back to drag them deep into their territory.
Jay Cutler committed his regularly scheduled turnover, this one a special little interception in the end zone in the third quarter.
You can yammer on about another last-minute drive that helped get the game to overtime, but there’s a turnover every game with this guy.
Trust him at your own risk. If you think he has suddenly changed into a different guy, you’re kidding yourself. He’s the same guy with the same tendencies to make soul-crushing mistakes.
Fox’s defense turned out to be as miserable as his clock management. I mean, 37 points to the Lions? A team that struggles to score 21?
The Lions entered the game with one of the NFL’s worst offenses, but the Bears allowed 546 total yards and 353 in the air, including a 57-yard bomb to set up the winning field goal in overtime.
Who’s the genius who let Harold Jones-Quartey take Calvin Johnson deep in overtime?
The one real threat the Lions have, and the Bears let him make the biggest play of the game.
The winless Lions apparently haven't cornered the market on ugly play and bad coaching.
 Detroit Lions Matthew Stafford Calvin Johnson Golden Tate
